fr:title.text: Identity morphisms in a regular category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity morphisms in a regular category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to A is the identity morphism iff x\colon A|\top \vdash f(x) = x is satisfied.

Suppose that f is the identity morphism. Then by , {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}} is \mathsf {id}_{A} \circ {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}. But the equalizer with itself is the terminal object. Thus, \top \leq {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x) = x\rrbracket \mathclose {}} in \mathsf {Sub}(A) as required.

Conversely, suppose that the terminal object of \mathsf {Sub}(A) (i.e., the identity morphism \mathsf {id}_{A}) factors through {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x) = x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}. Then it follows that \mathsf {id}_{A} equalizes {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}. Since {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}} = \mathsf {id}_{A} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket f\rrbracket \mathclose {}} = f, it follows that f = \mathsf {id}_{A}.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with sufficient structure and \Gamma = x_{1}\colon B_{1},\ldots ,x_{m}\colon B_{m} be a context over a signature \Sigma . Given a \Sigma -structure M in \mathcal {C}, the interpretation of a term-in-context \Gamma .t of sort B in M is a morphism {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .t\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M}\colon M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})\to MB defined recursively on the structure of t as follow:

fr:ul.fr:li: {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .x_{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the i-th projection \pi _{i}\colon M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})\to MB_{i}.

If f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B is a function symbol and t_{1},\ldots ,t_{n} are terms of appropriate sorts then {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .f(t_{1},\ldots ,t_{n})\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the composite M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) \xrightarrow {({\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .t_{1}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .t_{n}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M})} M(A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}) \xrightarrow {Mf} MB

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category \mathcal {C} is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be a regular functor and f\colon A\to B be a morphism in \mathcal {C}. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F(\mathsf {Img}(f))F(\vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf {Img}(Ff) \cong F(\mathsf {Img}(f)).
